Definition: Given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>, where Head and Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants, and the names of specific people have been replaced by generic words, you have to determine whether the Head is capable of the Tail or not. Being capable of something includes general capabilities, such as a human is capable of thinking and reasoning or drinking coffee, as well as specialized capabilities, such as a surgeon is capable of operating on a patient. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.
Domains: Commonsense -> Concepts and Relations -> Social Commonsense

Positive Examples.explanation: This is a good example. The Head is capable of the Tail.

Positive Examples.input: Head: PersonX accomplishes PersonY's work<sep>Tail: satisfied
Positive Examples.explanation: In this example, being capable of satisfied doesn't make sense. So the output should be"No".
In this example, the warder is capable of leaving the jail. Thus, this example should be classified as "Yes".

Negative Examples.input: Head: PersonX achieves PersonY end<sep>Tail: to be alone
Negative Examples.explanation: In this example, PersonX achieves PersonY end is/are capable of being alone doesn't make sense. So the output should be "No".
The scientist is capable of discovering new things, and the output should be "Yes".

Instances.input: Head: PersonX accepts the dare<sep>Tail: to prove they are not afraid
Head: PersonX accidentally stepped<sep>Tail: to turn around
